Problem:
Consider a fluid flow governed by the Navier-Stokes equation under various conditions. We analyze the impact of a non-linear transformation defined by the function \\( g(v) = \\sinh(kv) \\) where k is a constant, on the initial velocity profile \\( v(x, 0) \\) of the fluid.

If the transformation \\( g(v) \\) is applied to the initial velocity profile \\( v(x, 0) \\) and then allowed to evolve under the Navier-Stokes equation without further intervention, will the velocity profile \\( v(x, t) \\) at time t = T be the same as if the initial profile was directly evolved to t = T under the Navier-Stokes equation?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(v) \\) significantly alters the initial conditions by introducing non-linearities. The behavior of the system under the Navier-Stokes equation will be fundamentally different due to the altered initial state, resulting in a different velocity profile at any future time T.
